html:
NEW YORK, Feb 11 (IFR) - Today’s red-hot inflation reading provided another setback to hopes for a near-term rebound in US ECM.

Just when it looked as if investors might be returning to their default bullishness and IPO launch discussions seemed to be getting serious again, the DJIA tumbled 526.47 points (-1.47%) as investors digested CPI data showing a 0.6% increase in consumer prices in January.

It was the seventh time in the past 10 months the reading had risen more than 0.5%, while the year-on-year increase of 7.5% was the highest in 40 years.

Challenging the optimistic theory that Fed officials are more dovish than the bond market, St Louis Fed president James Bullard chimed in that the data had made him dramatically more hawkish and he wanted to see a full percentage point Fed funds rate rise by July 1.

Futures markets are now pricing in a nearly 90% chance of a 50bp rate rise (up from 24% yesterday) at the next FOMC meeting on March 15-16.

That is almost five weeks away, an eternity for US ECM bankers eager to get some Q1 fees under their belt.

One senior ECM banker said he was still confident that Q1 would bring some IPOs but conceded issuance would be “news flow and data-dependent”.

The next Fed meeting could be “a little bit of a bogeyman” for capital markets, another ECM banker said.

“Not that you want to be too scared of it but it’s an event that’s going to be closely followed to see what the outlook for rates is,” the second banker said.

Already the buyside was showing “no fear of missing out on IPOs like last year”.

The more guarded tone is also reflected in the earnings season as companies seek to emphasize their cashflow generation.

An unlikely example this week was Uber Technologies, whose Q4 results late yesterday saw a substantial improvement at the adjusted Ebitda line and included a guide towards greater profitability this year (thought the stock still fell 6.1% today).

“You are seeing the symptoms of higher rates. People are still focused on top-line growth but are highlighting operating leverage, cashflow and profitability a little bit more,” the second banker said.

Unfortunately, the earnings season brought more disappointment today from the struggling 2021 IPO class.

Shares of Max Levchin’s Affirm slumped 21.4% after the “buy now, pay later” firm dropped its fiscal Q2 results early via Twitter and its full-year revenue outlook came up short.

One of last year’s best performing IPOs out of the gate (the stock nearly doubled on debut in January 2022), Affirm closed today’s session at $58.68, still above its $49.00 price but down precipitously from $176.65 in November.

In the absence of IPOs and (very little) follow-on activity, and benefiting from market volatility, the most interesting deal flow this week is coming from the CB market.

Having already availed itself of the full suite of capital market product during the pandemic, serial issuer Norwegian Cruise Line (Wall Street’s new favorite customer?) embarked on a $435m exchangeable bond today as part of broader financing (more below).

Cruise lines (more so than airlines) remain a live prospect for ECM deals as they continue to work on shoring up their liquidity and addressing their debt-laden balance sheets post-Covid.

But if 2021 was the year for everyone to sell stock at a high (inflated?) price, then 2022 might be a time to buy it back at (substantially) lower prices.

Less than a year after it raised $1.25bn from a zero-coupon CB that allows holders to convert at share prices above $130.03, micro-blogger Twitter today revealed a $4bn buyback, including a $2bn accelerated share repurchase.

Twitter shares closed at $37.08, making the sell-high, buy-low turnabout an astute bit of corporate finance (though it will still owe the money back but not until 2026).

Of course, there were many examples last year of tech companies opportunistically raising equity capital at very attractive terms (that is, because they could rather than having a specific use of proceeds).

Still, buying back stock, along with M&A, could be crucial to putting a floor under sector valuations.

Even Amazon is buying back stock for the first time since 2012, revealing last week it repurchased $1.3bn of stock in January.

Back to port...again

Still charting a course out of the stormy seas it has had to navigate for nearly two years, Norwegian Cruise Line dipped into the market today with a three-part $2bn combo equity-linked and bond financing to take out remaining high-cost funding the cruise ship operator took on at the height of Covid-19 in 2020.

Norwegian remains saddled with $11.9bn of long-term debt, so realistically this refinancing is like chipping ice off an iceberg.

In any case, JP Morgan, Goldman Sachs and Mizuho Securities acted as joint books on the three-pronged sale of a $435m five-year convertible, $1bn of five-year secured notes, and $600m of seven-year unsecured notes.

Norwegian also revealed it expects to report $1.6bn–$1.8bn of adjusted Ebitda losses on revenue of just $600m–$800m for 2021. Liquidity stood at $2.7bn at the end of the year, down from $3.3bn at the end of 2020.

It is using the proceeds to take out the remaining $962.5m of 10.25% and 12.25% debt outstanding to reduce interest expense but paying a premium to do so.

The new 2027 and 2029 debt is being sold at 6.25%–6.5% and 8%–8.25% annual coupons, implying a roughly $40m saving in annual interest expenses.

Norwegian’s latest venture into capital markets is also about staunching the heavy dilution shareholders have suffered as the company repeatedly sold stock to weather the pandemic – through multiple equity offerings, Norwegian has nearly doubled shares outstanding to 416.9m since the pandemic began.

Here it is paying a higher coupon on the CB (2.5%-3%) in return for a higher conversion premium (47.5%–52.5%). The new CB can also be settled entirely in cash, or a combination of stock and cash, enabling the company to manage the amount of stock issued upon conversion.

“We have seen a lot of interest from fundamental investors seeking to add exposure to the name,” said one equity-linked banker. “I suspect the CB prices at the tight-end of price talk.”

Norwegian shares fell 4.6% to $22.63 today, implying a conversion price on the new CB of about $34.00.

This refinancing is similar to the one undertaken in November that saw the cruise ship operator raise $2.25bn from the concurrent sale of 46.9m shares at $23.64 and a 1.125% CB maturing in February 2027 at share prices above $33.69, a 42.5% premium.

This time around, Norwegian is having to pay a make-whole premium to take out the 10.25s and 12.25s, costing it about 120% of par. In November, it was able to exercise equity claw-back provisions to take them out at 110.25% and 112.25%, respectively.

This is all about positioning the slow-moving Norwegian if and/or when earnings begin to flow, which could happen this year assuming the worst of Covid really is behind the battered cruise industry.

Buzzed

Faced with dwindling cash and ongoing need for money, Vera Therapeutics last night raised the $75m it was looking for but only by offering investors a massive concession.

After two days of marketing, JP Morgan, Cowen and Evercore priced 5m Vera shares at $15.00, a gaping 21.3% discount to the $19.05 last sale and a 26.4% file-to-offer discount. The offering was upsized by 20% from 4m at launch.

Vera shares closed today’s session at $17.80, delivering a positive mark for investors that participated.

The same tight group of investors that supported Vera to date, including via its $48m IPO priced at $11.00 in May last year, likely underpinned demand for the offering.

Vera, as we pointed out in Tuesday’s briefing, is barely public with just 10 institutions owning more than 80% of the biotech. The stock barely trades at all. Just 900,000 shares changed hands today.

Vera plans to spend $75m on drug development this year, including $60m for a Phase III trial on a lupus drug and the other $15m on a Phase II trial on a drug it recently acquired from Pfizer.

The biotech had just $79.7m of cash at December 31.

Vera believes the $155m of cash it will carry post-offering is enough to keep it going through the middle of 2024.

Piping down

Like most other investment banks, Piper Sandler ended a record 2021 for ECM with a Q4 slowdown in activity that has spilled into early 2022.

Reporting its latest results today, Piper said its Q4 corporate financing revenues (largely ECM) fell 25% versus the same quarter in 2020 (and 18% versus Q3).

The firm participated in 45 equity transactions, down 10% versus the linked quarter, though book-run equity transactions rose 14% to 33.

This reflected solid contributions from the healthcare, financial services, consumer and technology sectors, the firm said.

Though some firms have not openly conceded as much yet, Piper CEO Chad Abraham told analysts he expected equity issuance to decline “substantially” this year from the record levels of the past two years.

Abraham said the first five to six weeks of 2022 had been “incredibly slow” in ECM, though this was not the first time this had happened in the past four or five years and rarely did it last for a whole quarter.

Asked if clients were simply delaying their IPOs or canceling them altogether, Abraham said: “I would say what happens is you have to get a few clients (on the IPO side) to sort of be first and test the market and get some good results.

“They want to do the transaction and you just need less volatility. And it takes a few weeks after the market stabilizes and then you start to see clients go.”

Though some banks expect follow-on activity to return more quickly than IPOs, Abraham said healthcare/biotech issuance could take “a little bit longer” because it depended on share prices.

Even with the Q4 moderation, Piper reported record corporate finance revenues of $362.8m in 2021, up 23% from a robust 2020.

For the year, the firm completed 214 equity transactions, 141 of which were bookrun.

Abraham noted the US equity issuance fee pool surpassed $20bn for the first time last year, more than double the 10-year average, while the fee pool for sub-$5bn market cap companies in healthcare alone was $3.6bn, nearly double the decade average.

“Innovation, investor demand and significant capital requirements have led healthcare companies to raise record amounts of money,” he said.

“We believe there is a structural change in the size of the healthcare financing market that will support higher levels of activity relative to historical averages.”

Links

Crypto exchange Binance invests $200m in Forbes via SPAC PIPE funding.

Credit Suisse flags weak 2022, ends torrid year with $2.2bn quarterly loss.

Twitter to buy back $4bn of stock, including $2bn via an ASR.

Warburg Pincus acquires Informa’s pharma intelligence unit for $2.6bn.

Zendesk rejects unsolicited private equity offers at $127-$132 per share.

Zillow soars on upbeat outlook, faster-than-expected run-off of home-flipping operation.

Priced

Monday

Aurora Technology Acquisition (Singapore, SPAC) – $200m IPO. 20m units (100% prim) at $10.00. Each unit comprises one share, one warrant and one-tenth right. MAXM. Nasdaq “ATAKU”. Zachary Wang, Cathryn Chen, Yida Gao. Tech (Asian-American entrepreneurs). 12 months. 100% in trust. Priced pre-open Monday.

Colony Bankcorp (US, bank) – $55m FO. 3.35m shares (100% prim) at $16.50 versus $17.02 last sale. HOVD, JSM.

Equitable Bank (Canada, banking) – C$200m ($158m) Bought deal. 2.84m subscription receipts (100% prim) at C$70.50 versus C$73.40 last sale. TD, RBC. Buying Concentra Bank for C$470m ($370m).

LIV Capital Acquisition II (Mexico, SPAC) – $100m IPO. 10m units (100% prim) at $10.00. Each unit comprises one share and three-quarters warrant. EBC. LIV Capital. Mexico. 15 months. 102% in trust.

Tuesday

byNordic Acquisition (Sweden, SPAC) – $150m SPAC IPO. 15m units at $10.00. Each unit comprises one share and one-half warrant. KBW, DREX, IBNK. Nasdaq “BYNOU”. Jonas Olsson. Tech, Europe. 15 months. 102% in trust.

Counter Press Acquisitio n (US, SPAC) – $75m IPO. 7.5m units (100% prim) at $10.00. Each unit comprises one share and one-half warrant. BTIG, EBC. Nasdaq “CPAQU”. Paul Conway, Michael Kalt. Sports media. 12 months. 101.5% in trust.

Equatorial Energia (Brazil, utility) – R$2.8bn ($530m) FO. 118.4m shares (100% prim) at R$23.50 versus R$23.76 last sale and R$$22.65 at launch. CS, CITI, UBS, XP, GS. Upsized from 87.7m shares with 35% hot issue provision.

Evergreen (Malaysia, SPAC) – $100m IPO. 10m units (100% prim) at $10.00. Each unit comprises one share and one warrant. EFH. Nasdaq “EVGRU”. Liew Choon Lian. Tech. 12 months. 101.5% in trust.

Snap (US, social media) – $1.3bn 6y cvt priced at 0.125%, up 50% versus 0.125%-0.625% and 45%-50% marketing. JPM, MS, GS. Upsized from $1.25bn. Capped call to $93.90, a 150% premium.

Wednesday

Vera Therapeutics (US, biotech) – $75m FO. 4.99m shares (100% prim) at $15.00 versus $19.05 last sale and $20.37 at launch. JPM, COWN, EVER. Went public in May 2021 at $11.00 a share. Upsized from 4m shares.

Thursday

HNR Acquisition (US, SPAC) – $75m IPO. 7.5m units (100% prim) at $10.00. Each unit comprises one share and three-fourths of a warrant. EFH. NYSE American “HNRAU”. Houston Natural Resources. E&P. 12 months. 102% in trust.

Jaguar Global Growth Corporation I (US, SPAC) – $200m IPO. 20m units (100% prim) at $10.00. Each unit comprises one share and one-half warrant. CITI, BARC. Nasdaq “JGGCU”. Jaguar Growth Partners. Proptech. 18 months. 102% in trust.

Withdrawn

Crucible Acquisition III (US, SPAC) – $350m IPO. CS. Foundry Group (James Lejeal, Brad Feld). Software.

High Cape Capital Acquisition II (US, SPAC) – $200m IPO. CANT. HighCape. Kevin Rakin. Life sciences.

The daily IFR US ECM Briefing covers US, Canadian and Latin American IPOs, as well as secondary and convertible offerings in those markets. For further information or to arrange a trial, contact client support.
